sentence.text: Abnormal prion proteins are responsible for several fatal neurodegenerative diseases in humans and in animals, including Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (positive regulation of peptidyl-tyrosine phosphorylation), Gerstmann-StrÃ¤ussler-Scheinker disease, and fatal familial insomnia.

In addition, different prion mutations were suggested to play a possible role in additional phenocardiac muscle tissue developments, such as Alzheimer's cardiac muscle tissue development pathology, spongiform encephalopathy, or frontotemporal dementia.

Since prion diseases have quite heterogeneous phenocardiac muscle tissue developments, a complex analysis, a combination of genetic screening, cerebrospinal fluid biomarker analysis and imaging technologies could improve the early disease diagnosis
